member.name: T:Eto.AutoInitializeAttribute
member.summary: Attribute to specify whether the handler interface should be initialized automatically
member.remarks:
Handler interfaces that defer creation of the control to various Create() methods can apply this attribute so that the initialization can be done afterwards.
If auto initialization is disabled, the widget author must call Widget.Initialize() after the control is created.
Initialization applies styles to the widget and the handler, sets up events based on overridden event methods, etc.
This is only needed by widget authors in advanced scenarios. The default is to auto initialize, so this is only needed if you want to disable this behaviour.

member.name: P:Eto.AutoInitializeAttribute.Initialize
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether to auto initialize the handler, false to defer this to the widget author

member.name: M:Eto.AutoInitializeAttribute.#ctor(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: If set to true initialize the widget automatically, otherwise false.

member.name: T:Eto.CollectionChangedHandler`2
member.summary: Class to help implement collection changed events on a data store
member.remarks:
This is used for the platform handler of controls that use collections. This class helps detect changes to a collection so that the appropriate action can be taken to update the UI with the changes.
This is a simple helper that is much easier to implement than handling the event directly.
member.typeparam: Type of the items in the collection
Type of the collection

member.summary: Gets the collection that this handler is observing

member.summary: Called when the object has been registered (attached) to a collection

member.summary: Called when the object has unregistered the collection

member.summary: Unregisters the current registered collection

member.summary: Inserts an item at the specified index in the collection

member.summary: Removes the item at the specified index

member.summary: Removes all items from the collection

member.name: M:Eto.CollectionChangedHandler`2.RemoveItem(`0)
member.summary: Removes the specified item
member.remarks: This will remove the item by finding the index and removing based on index. Implementors should override this method if there is a faster mechanism to do so.
member.param: Item to remove from the collection

member.name: M:Eto.CollectionChangedHandler`2.AddRange(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{`0})
member.summary: Adds multiple items to the end of the collection
member.remarks:
This simply calls for each item in the list. If there is a faster mechanism for doing so, implementors should override this method.
For example, sometimes adding a single item will update the UI for each item, this should be overridden so the UI is updated after all items have been added.
member.param: Enumeration of items to add to the end of the collection

member.name: M:Eto.CollectionChangedHandler`2.InsertRange(System.Int32,System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{`0})
member.summary: Inserts multiple items to the specified index in the collection
member.remarks:
This simply calls for each item in the list. If there is a faster mechanism for doing so, implementors should override this method.
For example, sometimes inserting a single item will update the UI for each item, this should be overridden so the UI is updated after all items have been inserted.
member.param: Index to start adding the items

member.name: M:Eto.CollectionChangedHandler`2.RemoveRange(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Removes a specified count of items from the collection starting at the specified index
member.remarks:
This simply calls for each item to remove. If there is a faster mechanism for doing so, implementors should override this method.
For example, sometimes removing a single item will update the UI for each item, this should be overridden so the UI is updated after all items have been removed.
member.param: Index to start removing the items from

member.name: M:Eto.CollectionChangedHandler`2.RemoveRange(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{`0})
member.summary: Removes the specified items from the collection
member.remarks:
This simply calls for each item to remove. If there is a faster mechanism for doing so, implementors should override this method.
For example, sometimes removing a single item will update the UI for each item, this should be overridden so the UI is updated after all items have been removed.

member.name: M:Eto.Drawing.Bitmap.WithSize(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets an Icon representation of this Bitmap scaled to draw within the specified fitting size.
member.remarks: This is useful when you want to draw the image at a different size than the default size without resizing the image. Note that the and specifies the maxiumum drawing size of the Icon, but will not change the aspect of each frame's bitmap. For example, if an existing frame is 128x128, and you specify 16x32, then the resulting frame will draw at 16x16.
member.returns: A new icon that will draw within the fitting size.
member.param: Maxiumum drawing width for the new icon.
Maxiumum drawing height for the new icon.

member.name: T:Eto.Drawing.BitmapData
member.summary: Bitmap data information when accessing a 's data directly
member.remarks:
The bitmap data is accessed through , which locks the data for direct access using the pointer.
Ensure you call dispose the instance when you are done accessing or writing the data, otherwise the bitmap may be left in an unusable state.

member.name: M:Eto.Drawing.BitmapData.TranslateArgbToData(System.Int32)
member.summary: Translates a 32-bit ARGB value to the platform specific pixel format value
member.remarks:
Use this method to translate an ARGB (Alpha in most significant) to the value required by the bitmap for the pixel.
Each platform can have a different pixel format, and this allows you to abstract setting the data directly.
The ARGB value can be easily retrieved using .
For non-alpha bitmaps, the alpha component will be ignored
member.param: ARGB pixel value to translate into the platform-specific format
member.returns: Platform-specific format of the pixels that can be set directly onto the data

member.name: M:Eto.Drawing.BitmapData.TranslateDataToArgb(System.Int32)
member.summary: Translates the platform specific pixel format to a 32-bit ARGB value
member.remarks:
Use this method to translate an value from the bitmap data to a 32-bit ARGB (Alpha in most significant byte).
Each platform can have a different pixel format, and this allows you to abstract getting the data into a 32-bit colour.
The ARGB value can be easily handled using .
For non-alpha bitmaps, the alpha component will be ignored
member.param: Platform specific bitmap data for a pixel to translate
member.returns: Translated ARGB value from the bitmap data

member.name: P:Eto.Drawing.BitmapData.Data
member.summary: Gets the pointer to the data of the bitmap
member.remarks:
This does not include any headers, etc. so it directly points to the beginning of the data.
Each row may not be on a pixel boundary, so to increment to the next row, use the to increment the pointer to the next row.

member.name: P:Eto.Drawing.BitmapData.Flipped
member.summary: Gets a value indicating that the data is flipped (upside down)
member.remarks:
Some platforms may handle memory bitmaps in a flipped fashion, such that the top of the image is at the bottom of the data.
If this is true, then the starting row of the data is the bottom row of the image.

members.member:
Calculates the distance of the two colors in the RGB scale
This is useful for comparing two different color values to determine if they are similar.
Typically though, gives the best result instead of using the RGB method. First color to compare Second color to compare with The overall distance/difference between the two colours. A lower value indicates a closer match

member.name: M:Eto.Drawing.Color.Blend(Eto.Drawing.Color,Eto.Drawing.Color)
member.summary: Blends the onto the specified
member.remarks: This computes the blended value of two colors.
member.param: Color to blend onto the base color

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the Color object with the specified red, green, blue, and alpha components

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the Color object as a copy of the specified
member.param: Alpha to use for the new color, or null to use the alpha component from

member.name: M:Eto.Drawing.Color.TryParse(System.String,Eto.Drawing.Color@)
member.summary: Converts the specified string to a color
member.remarks:
The string can be any of these formats: - #AARRGGBB or #RRGGBB (where ARGB are hex values) - 0xAARRGGBB or 0xRRGGBB - [named] (where [named] is a name of one of the properties in ) - [uint] (where [uint] is a base-10 ARGB value) - [red], [green], [blue] (where each component is a value from 0-255) - [alpha], [red], [green], [blue] (where each component is a value from 0-255)
If the string is null or empty, this will return
member.param: Color struct with the parsed value, or Transparent if value is invalid
member.returns: True if the value was successfully parsed into a color, false otherwise

member.name: M:Eto.Drawing.Color.Parse(System.String)
member.summary: Converts a string into a new instance of a Color
member.remarks: Use instead of try/catch.
member.exception: If the value is an invalid color

member.summary: Tests if the specified object has the same value as this Color
member.returns: True if the specified object is a Color and has the same ARGB components as this color, false otherwise

member.summary: Compares two Color structs for equality

The second Color struct to compare
member.returns: True if both the Color structs have the same values for all ARGB components

member.name: M:Eto.Drawing.Color.op_Inequality(Eto.Drawing.Color,Eto.Drawing.Color)
member.summary: Compares two Color structs for inequality
member.param: The first Color struct to compare
The second Color struct to compare
member.returns: True if the Color structs have a differing value for any of the ARGB components

member.name: M:Eto.Drawing.Color.Invert
member.summary: Inverts the RGB color values
member.remarks: This inverts the color components (other than the alpha component) by making them equal to the 1 minus the component's value. This is useful for when you want to show a highlighted color but still show the variation in colors.

member.name: M:Eto.Drawing.Color.ToArgb
member.summary: Converts this color to a 32-bit ARGB value.
member.returns: The 32-bit ARGB value that corresponds to this color

member.name: M:Eto.Drawing.Color.ToHex(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Converts this color to a hex representation
member.remarks: This will either return a hex value with 8 digits (two per component), or 6 digits (two per RGB) if the is set to false.
member.param: True to include the alpha component, false to exclude it
member.returns: A hex representation of this color, with 8 digits if is true, or 6 digits if false

member.returns: A string representation of this object

member.name: M:Eto.Drawing.Color.Equals(Eto.Drawing.Color)
member.summary: Compares the specified color for equality
member.returns: True if all components of the specified color are equal to this object

member.name: M:Eto.Drawing.Color.FromElementId(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates a new color from an Element ID value
member.remarks: This algorithm is from the SVG# code base: The counter is used to generate IDs in the range [0,2^24-1] The 24 bits of the counter are interpreted as follows: [red 7 bits | green 7 bits | blue 7 bits |shuffle term 3 bits] The shuffle term is used to define how the remaining high bit is set on each color. The colors are generated in the range [0,127] (7 bits) instead of [0,255]. Then the shuffle term is used to adjust them into the range [0,255]. This algorithm has the feature that consecutive ids generate visually distinct colors.
member.returns: A new instance of a Color with the value from the element id

member.name: M:Eto.Drawing.Color.ToElementId
member.summary: Converts this color to an Element ID value
member.returns: The element id value of this color

member.name: M:Eto.Drawing.Color.System#IComparable{Eto#Drawing#Color}#CompareTo(Eto.Drawing.Color)
member.summary: Compares two colors for sorting Colors in standard collections.
member.returns: A signed value indicating whether this instance is greater, less, or equal to other.
member.param: The other color value to compare with.

member.returns: A new ColorHSB structure.

member.summary: Represents a color in the CMYK color model.
member.remarks: This is a helper class to handle CMYK colors. Whenever a color is used it must be converted to a struct first, either by using or the implicit conversion.

member.name: T:Eto.Drawing.ColorHSB
member.summary: Color representation in HSB color model
member.remarks:
This allows you to manage a color in the HSB (otherwise known as HSV) cylindrical model.
This is a helper class to handle HSB colors. Whenever a color is used it must be converted to a struct first, either by using or the implicit conversion.

member.name: T:Eto.Drawing.ColorHSL
member.summary: Color representation in the HSL color model
member.remarks:
This allows you to manage a color in the HSL cylindrical model.
This is a helper class to handle HSL colors. Whenever a color is used it must be converted to a struct first, either by using or the implicit conversion.

member.name: P:Eto.Drawing.ColorHSL.A
member.summary: Gets or sets the alpha (0-1)

member.name: P:Eto.Drawing.ColorHSL.H
member.summary: Gets or sets the hue (0-360)

member.name: P:Eto.Drawing.ColorHSL.S
member.summary: Gets or sets the saturation (0-1)

member.name: P:Eto.Drawing.ColorHSL.L
member.summary: Gets or sets the luminance (0-1)

member.name: M:Eto.Drawing.ColorHSL.Distance(Eto.Drawing.ColorHSL,Eto.Drawing.ColorHSL)
member.summary: Calculates the 'distance' of two HSL colors
member.remarks:
This is useful for comparing two different color values to determine if they are similar.
The HSL comparison algorithm, while not essentially accurate, gives a good representation of like-colours to the human eye. This method of calculating distance is preferred over the other methods (RGB, CMYK, HSB)
member.returns: The overall distance/difference between the two colours. A lower value indicates a closer match

member.name: T:Eto.Drawing.DashStyle
member.summary: Dash style for a

member.name: P:Eto.Drawing.DashStyle.Dashes
member.summary: Gets the dashes and gaps for this style
member.remarks:
The values specified are the dash lengths and gap lengths in alternating order. The lengths are multiplied by the thickness of the pen.
For example, values of 2, 1 would have a dash of (2 * thickness) followed by a gap of (1 * thickness).
member.value: The dashes to use for a pen

member.name: P:Eto.Drawing.DashStyle.Offset
member.summary: Gets the offset of the first dash
member.remarks: A value of 1 indicates that the first dash should start at the (1*thickness) of the pen.
member.value: The offset of the first dash, in multiples of pen thickness

member.returns: True if successful, or false if the value could not be parsed

member.name: T:Eto.Drawing.Font
member.summary: Defines a format for text
member.remarks:
A font is typically defined with a specified font family, with a given typeface. Each typeface has certain characteristics that define the variation of the font family, for example Bold, or Italic.
You can get a list of objects available in the current system using , which can then be used to create an instance of a font.

The font families here may correspond to certain fonts on each system, depending on the platform.

member.name: T:Eto.Drawing.FontFamily
member.summary: Specifies a family for a object
member.remarks:
A font family defines the overall look of the font, such as "Times New Roman", "Helvetica", etc.
Each family consists of one or more , which define the variations of each font family. The variations can include Light, Bold, Italic, Oblique, etc. Only the styles in are discoverable, other than looking at the for hints as to what the variation will look like.

member.name: P:Eto.Drawing.FontFamily.Name
member.summary: Gets the name of this font family
member.remarks: This is a non-localized version of the name, suitable for internal use.

member.name: P:Eto.Drawing.FontFamily.LocalizedName
member.summary: Gets the localized name of the font for the current UI language
member.remarks:
This will return a name suitable to display to the user in their own language, if the font provides a specific name for their UI language.
For platforms that do not support localized font names, or for fonts that do not have a specific name for the current language, the value of will be returned.
member.value: The localized name of this font.

member.name: P:Eto.Drawing.Graphics.DPI
member.summary: Gets the dots per inch of the current graphics context. Usually 96 for windows and 72 for other systems

member.name: P:Eto.Drawing.Graphics.PointsPerPixel
member.summary: Gets the scale of points per pixel. Multiply by pixel size to get point value (e.g. to set font size in pixels).
member.remarks: A value of 1.0 indicates that one point equals one pixel. Windows is usually 0.75 (96 dpi) while other systems are usually 1.0 (e.g. linux, os x)

member.name: P:Eto.Drawing.Graphics.PixelsPerPoint
member.summary: Gets the scale of points to pixels. Multiply by point value to get pixel size
member.remarks: A value of 1.0 indicates that one pixel equals one point. Windows is usually 1 1/3 (96 dpi) while other systems are usually 1.0 (e.g. linux, os x)

member.name: P:Eto.Drawing.Graphics.PixelOffsetMode
member.summary: Gets or sets the pixel offset mode for draw operations

member.name: P:Eto.Drawing.Graphics.IsRetained
member.summary: Gets a value indicating the graphics sub-system is a retained system (e.g. WPF)
member.remarks: Retained mode systems may have different behaviour characteristics, which may impact how often the screen is updated or other code.

member.name: M:Eto.Drawing.Graphics.Flush
member.summary: Flushes the drawing (for some platforms)
member.remarks:
Flushing the drawing will force any undrawn changes to be shown to the user. Typically when you are doing a lot of drawing, you may want to flush the changed periodically so that the user does not think the UI is unresponsive.
Some platforms may not have the concept of flushing the graphics, so this would do nothing

member.name: T:Eto.Drawing.Graphics.TransformState
member.summary: Maintains the current state of the graphics object.

member.name: M:Eto.Drawing.Graphics.SaveTransformState
member.summary: Gets an object that will restore to the current transform state when disposed.
member.remarks:
This saves the current transform state that can be changed by any of the transform calls.
This is useful when calling into untrusted code that can leave the transform unbalanced. It also ensures that RestoreTransform() requires a matching SaveTransform(), until the return value is disposed. Disposing the return value guarantees that the transform state is restored to when this method was called.

member.name: M:Eto.Drawing.Graphics.SaveTransform
member.summary: Saves the current transform state
member.remarks: This saves the current transform state that can be changed by any of the transform calls, which can then be restored using

member.name: M:Eto.Drawing.Graphics.RestoreTransform
member.summary: Restores the transform state
member.remarks: This restores the transform state from a previous call. You must balance calls to SaveTransform() with calls to this method.

member.name: P:Eto.Drawing.Graphics.CurrentTransform
member.summary: Gets a copy of the current transform.
member.remarks: The current transform is initially an identity matrix. Any transform operations performed on this object will change this value.

member.name: P:Eto.Drawing.Graphics.ClipBounds
member.summary: Gets the bounds of the clipping region
member.remarks: This rectangle will encompass all parts of the clipping region, which may not be rectangular in shape
member.value: The clip bounds applied to drawing operations

member.name: M:Eto.Drawing.Graphics.SetClip(Eto.Drawing.RectangleF)
member.summary: Sets the clip region to the specified
member.remarks: The previous clipping region will be cleared after this call. The rectangle specified is translated by the current transform, but is not affected by subsequent transform operations.

member.name: M:Eto.Drawing.Graphics.SetClip(Eto.Drawing.IGraphicsPath)
member.summary: Sets the clip region to the specified
member.remarks: The previous clipping region will be cleared after this call The path specified is translated by the current transform, but is not affected by subsequent transform operations.
member.param: Path to specify the clip region

member.name: M:Eto.Drawing.Graphics.ResetClip
member.summary: Resets the clip bounds to encompass the entire drawing area

member.name: M:Eto.Drawing.Graphics.IsVisible(Eto.Drawing.RectangleF)

member.name: T:Eto.Drawing.Icon
member.summary: Represents an icon which allows for multiple sizes and resolutions of an image
member.remarks:
The formats supported vary by platform, however all platforms do support loading windows .ico format.
Using an icon for things like menus, toolbars, etc are preferred so that each platform can use the appropriate sized image.
For High DPI/Retina displays (e.g. on OS X), this will allow using a higher resolution image automatically.

member.name: M:Eto.Drawing.Icon.WithSize(Eto.Drawing.Size)
member.summary: Gets a copy of this Icon with frames scaled to draw within the specified fitting size.
member.remarks: This is useful when you want to draw an Icon at a different size than the default size. Note that the specifies the maxiumum drawing size of the Icon, but will not change the aspect of each frame's bitmap. For example, if an existing frame is 128x128, and you specify 16x32, then the resulting frame will draw at 16x16.
member.returns: A new icon that will draw within the fitting size.
member.param: The maximum size to draw the Icon.

member.name: M:Eto.Drawing.Icon.WithSize(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets a copy of this Icon with frames scaled to draw within the specified fitting size.

Note that the and specifies the maxiumum drawing size of the Icon, but will not change the aspect of each frame's bitmap. For example, if an existing frame is 128x128, and you specify 16x32, then the resulting frame will draw at 16x16.
member.returns: A new icon that will draw within the fitting size.
member.param: Maxiumum drawing width for the new icon.
Maxiumum drawing height for the new icon.

member.name: T:Eto.Drawing.IconFrame
member.summary: Represents a frame in an .
member.remarks:
The IconFrame represents a single frame in an Icon. Each IconFrame can have a specific pixel size and scale, which will automatically be chosen based on the display and draw size of the image in various Eto controls.
You can load an icon from an .ico, where all frames will have a 1.0 scale (pixel size equals logical size)

member.summary: Enumeration of the pixel offset modes of a

member.name: F:Eto.Drawing.PixelOffsetMode.None
member.summary: Specifies that pixels will not be offset and be relative to the center of each pixel.
member.remarks: This simplifies drawing odd-width lines by aligning them to the pixel boundary.

member.name: F:Eto.Drawing.PixelOffsetMode.Half
member.summary: Specifies that pixels are offset by half a pixel (-0.5) in both the horizontal and vertical axes. Use for high speed.
member.remarks:
In this mode, the center of lines will be at the point between logical pixels and can improve performance with some platforms. Horizontal or vertical lines that are not a fraction will typically be antialiased. For example, to draw a 1px wide horizontal line without antialiasing, you would have to draw at a 0.5 offset in the vertical axis.
Only Draw operations are offset with this mode, Fill operations will not be offset. (new in 2.1) For example, filling a rectangle from 10, 10 to 20, 20 will not be antialiased and fall on (logical) pixel boundaries.

member.name: M:Eto.Drawing.Rectangle.Ceiling(Eto.Drawing.RectangleF)
member.summary: Converts a floating point to an integral by getting the smallest integral value of X, Y, Width, and Height
member.remarks: This is used to get an integral rectangle that bounds the floating point rectangle completely. E.g. if a RectangleF has (X,Y,W,H) values of 0.2, 0.9, 1.1, 1.9, it would return a new integral rectangle with values 0, 0, 2, 2.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.Application.MainForm
member.summary: Gets or sets the main form for your application.
member.remarks:
When you set this to your main application form, it will get standard platform behaviour applied, such as quitting the application when it is closed (on windows, linux), or showing the main form on OS X when clicking the application icon if it has been hidden/closed.
Setting this is optional, however you must then manually call when you want your application to quit in that case.
member.value: The main form for your application.

member.name: M:Eto.Forms.BindableBinding`2.Child``1(System.Linq.Expressions.Expression{System.Func{`0,``0}})
member.summary: Binds to the specified child expression.
member.remarks:
This can be used to bind to properties of child objects of your view model, for example model.SomeProperty.ChildProperty.
This will automatically look up the changed event either by a [Property]Changed event or INotifyPropertyChanged implementation for each object in the heirarchy.
Note that you only really need to use this when you have an existing binding that you cannot change. See for an example of how to bind to child property values more directly.
member.returns: The binding to the child property accessed through the current binding.
member.typeparam: The type of the child property value.

member.typeparam: The type of the child property value.

member.remarks:
This helper method is useful for binding general events to fire an that is in your view model. The command will only be executed if its returns true.
Most controls (e.g. ) have a special Command parameter that can be set instead, which takes into account the enabled state of the command and will enable/disable the control automatically.

Binding to get the ICommand from the data context
Parameter to pass to the command when executing or checking if it can execute.

member.summary: Binds to the specified child expression.
member.remarks:
This can be used to bind to properties of child objects of your view model, for example model.SomeProperty.ChildProperty.
This will automatically look up the changed event either by a [Property]Changed event or INotifyPropertyChanged implementation for each object in the heirarchy.
Note that you only really need to use this when you have an existing binding that you cannot change. See for an example of how to bind to child property values more directly.
member.returns: The binding to the child property accessed through the current binding.
member.typeparam: The type of the child property value.

member.name: T:Eto.Forms.DualBindingMode
member.summary: Mode of the
member.remarks: This specifies what direction the updates of each of the properties are automatically handled. Only properties that have a Changed event, or objects that implement will handle automatically updating the binding.

member.name: F:Eto.Forms.DualBindingMode.OneWay
member.summary: Binding will update the destination if the source property is changed

member.name: F:Eto.Forms.DualBindingMode.TwoWay
member.summary: Binding will update both the destination or source if updated on either the source or destination, respectively

member.name: F:Eto.Forms.DualBindingMode.OneWayToSource
member.summary: Binding will update the source if the destination property is changed

member.name: F:Eto.Forms.DualBindingMode.OneTime
member.summary: Binding will only set the destination from the source when initially bound
member.remarks: This is ideal when you want to set the values of the destination, then only update the source at certain times using the method.

member.name: F:Eto.Forms.DualBindingMode.Manual
member.summary: Binding will only update when the method is called.

member.name: M:Eto.Forms.IndirectBinding`1.AfterDelay(System.TimeSpan,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Specifies that the binding should only respond to change events after a delay.
member.remarks:
This is useful if the property/delegate that is bound is expensive to retrieve the new value, for example to dynamically generate a bitmap based on the state of the model, etc.
The boolean allows you to ensure that the binding is updated periodically when false (default), or true to wait for the delay period after the last change event.
member.param: The delay time span to wait after the value has changed before updating the binding.
true to reset the delay every time the event is fired, false to trigger the change at least by the delay interval since the last time it was triggered
member.returns: A binding that will delay the change event

member.name: M:Eto.Forms.IndirectBinding`1.AfterDelay(System.Double,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Specifies that the binding should only respond to change events after a delay.
member.remarks:
This is useful if the property/delegate that is bound is expensive to retrieve the new value, for example to dynamically generate a bitmap based on the state of the model, etc.
The boolean allows you to ensure that the binding is updated periodically when false (default), or true to wait for the delay period after the last change event.
member.param: The delay, in seconds to wait after the value has changed before updating the binding.
true to reset the delay every time the event is fired, false to trigger the change at least by the delay interval since the last time it was triggered
member.returns: A binding that will delay the change event

member.name: T:Eto.Forms.CustomCell
member.summary: Cell for controls to create custom content for the cell.
member.remarks:
The CustomCell is useful when you want to provide a fully custom implementation of a cell, including editable controls.
Note that some platforms bahave differently with a CustomCell, depending on the value of .
When false, the grid will use the event to paint the contents of each cell, and only use and when the cell is in edit mode.
When true, the and methods will be used for all cells, even when not in edit mode.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.CustomCell.SupportsControlView
member.summary: Gets a value indicating that the CustomCell on the current platform supports using a Control for its view mode. Gtk and WinForms only support custom controls when editing a cell.
member.remarks: When false, you must handle the event (or override ) to provide a view mode for the cell contents.
member.value: true if supports control view; otherwise, false.

member.summary: Creates a new CustomCell with instances of the specified type.
member.typeparam: The type of control to instantiate for the cell, which must have a default constructor.

member.summary: Gets or sets a delegate to create the contents of the cell.
member.remarks: You can also override the method in subclasses.
member.value: The delegate to create the cell content.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.CustomCell.GetIdentifier
member.summary: Gets or sets a delegate to get the identifier of the cell based on its content.
member.remarks:
When you have different controls on a per-row level, each variation must have an identifier string to allow the framework to cache the different types of cells to provide good performance.
This hooks into standard cell caching mechanisms in certain platforms, such as on the Mac.
member.value: The delegate to get the identifier for the cell.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.CustomCell.GetPreferredWidth
member.summary: Gets or sets a delegate to get the preferred width of the cell based on its content.
member.remarks: This may only be used when is false.
member.value: The delegate to get the preferred width of the cell.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.CustomCell.ConfigureCell
member.summary: Gets or sets a delegate to configure an cell when it is reused for a different row or the data changes.
member.remarks:
This should set up your control your cell content to be reused. If null, the DataContext of your control will be set to the row model instance.
Typically if you use MVVM data binding, you do not need to override the standard behaviour.
member.value: The delegate to configure an existing cell's control for a new row/model instance.

member.name: M:Eto.Forms.CustomCell.OnCreateCell(Eto.Forms.CellEventArgs)
member.summary: Creates an instance of the control for a cell.
member.remarks:

If you intend on creating a different type of cell control based on the item, you should also override
member.param: Arguments when creating the cell to get the row, item and state.
member.returns: The control to display in the cell.

member.summary: Creates the content control for the cell.
member.remarks: The control returned may be reused for other cells, so it is ideal to use MVVM data binding using BindDataContext() methods of your controls. This should return the same control for each row, otherwise the incorrect control may be shown on certain cells.

member.name: M:Eto.Forms.PropertyCellType.OnConfigure(Eto.Forms.CellEventArgs,Eto.Forms.Control)
member.summary: Configures the content control for the given cell information.
member.remarks:
When the DataContext changes on a cell, this will be called to configure the cell.
You are only required to override this when you are not using MVVM data binding with your controls created by .
member.param: Content control that was previously created with the OnCreate method.

member.name: T:Eto.Forms.PropertyCell
member.summary: A custom cell implementation that implements a generic method of showing different types of controls on a per row basis.
member.remarks:
This is ideal for things like showing a property grid to edit various properties of an object.
The way this works is by using the of each row to determine which to use from the collection. It calls on each to find a type that can display based on the value returned.
Each added to the cell must have a unique value for to ensure the correct control is shown in the cell. The identifier is used to cache the content controls generated by the PropertyCellType when displaying the same value for other rows while scrolling.
Ideally, the content control generated from the should use MVVM BindDataContext() methods for its children so that they are updated automatically when reused for different controls. This is not a requirement, however you must then implement/override the to update your control when the item/row is changed.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.PropertyCell.TypeBinding
member.summary: Gets or sets the binding to get the type for the

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.PropertyCell.Types
member.summary: Gets the list of types to use for each cell, in order of preference.
member.remarks: When attempting to use a type for a cell, the types collection is scanned in order for the first PropertyCellType that returns true for .
member.value: The list of types this property cell supports.

member.name: M:Eto.Forms.PropertyCell.OnCreateCell(Eto.Forms.CellEventArgs)
member.summary: Creates an instance of the control for a cell.
member.param: Arguments when creating the cell to get the row, item and state.
member.returns: The control to display in the cell.

member.name: M:Eto.Forms.PropertyCell.OnConfigureCell(Eto.Forms.CellEventArgs,Eto.Forms.Control)
member.summary: Configures an existing cell when it is reused for a different row or the data changes.
member.remarks:
This should set up your control your cell content to be reused. If null, the DataContext of your control will be set to the row model instance.
Typically if you use MVVM data binding, you do not need to override the standard behaviour.
member.param: Existing control to configure for the new cell and/or data

member.name: M:Eto.Forms.PropertyCell.OnGetIdentifier(Eto.Forms.CellEventArgs)
member.summary: Gets the identifier of the cell based on its content.
member.remarks:
When you have different controls on a per-row level, each variation must have an identifier string to allow the framework to cache the different types of cells to provide good performance.
This hooks into standard cell caching mechanisms in certain platforms, such as on the Mac.

member.name: T:Eto.Forms.ColorDialog
member.summary: Dialog for choosing a color
member.remarks:
The color dialog on some platforms may run asynchronously, and return immediately after the call. For example, on OS X the color picker is a non-modal shared tool window that stays on the screen until the user dismisses it.
You should always handle the event to determine when the value has changed.

member.name: M:Eto.Forms.Container.SetLogicalParent(Eto.Forms.Control)
member.summary: Sets the logical (non-visual) parent of the specified child control.
member.remarks:
This is used by layout containers that may use other Eto controls to layout its children that shouldn't be necessary for users to be concerned about.
For example, the uses a TableLayout internally (for now), but the TableLayout should not be part of the logical tree of controls.
If this is not set, then the logical parent of a child is the same as the visual parent.
member.param: Child to set the logical parent to this container.

member.name: M:Eto.Forms.Container.RemoveLogicalParent(Eto.Forms.Control)
member.summary: Removes the child control from the logical parent of this container.
member.remarks: This should be used from containers that use other Eto controls to layout its children but should not be part of the logical heirarchy.
member.param: Child to remove from this container as the logical parent.

member.name: M:Eto.Forms.Container.SetParent(Eto.Forms.Control,System.Action,Eto.Forms.Control)
member.summary: Sets the parent of the specified to this container
member.remarks:
This is used by container authors to set the parent of a child before it is added to the underlying platform control.
The parameter should call the handler method to add the child to the parent.
member.returns: true, if parent was set, false otherwise.
member.param: Method to assign the child to the handler
Previous child that the new child is replacing.

member.summary: Base for all visual UI elements
member.remarks: All visual user interface elements should inherit from this class to provide common functionality like binding, load/unload, and common events.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.Control.Loaded
member.summary: Gets a value indicating that the control is loaded onto a form, that is it has been created, added to a parent, and shown
member.remarks:
The method sets this value to true after cascading to all children (for a ) and calling the platform handler's implementation. It is called after adding to a loaded form, or when showing a new form.
The method will set this value to false when the control is removed from its parent

member.remarks: This is used to specify which controls are contained by this instance that are part of the visual tree. This should include all controls including non-logical Eto controls used for layout.

member.summary: Event identifier for handlers when attaching the event

member.name: E:Eto.Forms.Control.MouseDoubleClick
member.summary: Occurs when a mouse button is double clicked within the bounds of the control
member.remarks:
If you do not set the property to true, and the default behaviour of the control does not accept double clicks, the event will be called for each click of the mouse button.
For example, if the user clicks twice in succession, the following will be called: 1. MouseDown for the first click 2. MouseDoubleClick for the second click 3. If Handled has not been set in #2, MouseDown will be called a 2nd time

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.Control.Size
member.summary: Gets or sets the size of the control. Use -1 to specify auto sizing for either the width and/or height.
member.remarks:
Setting the size of controls is entirely optional as most controls will size themselves appropriately. When specifying a size, it will be used as the desired size of the control. The container will reposition and resize the control depending on the available size.
For a , it is preferred to set the instead, as various platforms have different sizes of window decorations, toolbars, etc.
member.value: The current size of the control

member.summary: Gets or sets the width of the control size.

member.summary: Raises the event.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.Control.Enabled
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether this is enabled and accepts user input.
member.remarks: Typically when a control is disabled, the user cannot do anything with the control (including for example, selecting text in a text control). Certain controls can have a 'Read Only' mode, such as which allows the user to select text, but not change its contents.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.Control.Visible
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether this is visible to the user.
member.remarks: When the visibility of a control is set to false, it will still occupy space in the layout, but not be shown. The only exception is for controls like the , which will hide a pane if the visibility of one of the panels is changed.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.Control.VisualParent
member.summary: Gets the visual container of this control, if any.
member.remarks: Some containers may use other Eto controls to layout its children, such as the . This will return the parent control that visually contains this control as opposed to which will return the logical parent.
member.value: The visual parent of this control.

Identifier of the parent control to find, or null to find by type only.

member.name: M:Eto.Forms.Control.Detach
member.summary: Detaches the control by removing it from its parent
member.remarks: This is essentially a shortcut to myControl.Parent.Remove(myControl);

member.name: M:Eto.Forms.Control.AttachNative
member.summary: Attaches the control for direct use in a native application
member.remarks:
Use this to use a control directly in a native application. Note that the native application must be running the same framework as the current platform. E.g. a WinForms application can use an Eto.Forms control when using the Eto.WinForms platform.
This prepares the control by firing the , , etc. events.

member.name: M:Eto.Forms.Control.DetachNative
member.summary: Detaches the control when it is used in a native application, when you want to reuse the control.
member.remarks: This should only be called after has been called, which is usually done by calling to ToNative(true).

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.Control.BackgroundColor
member.summary: Gets or sets the color for the background of the control
member.remarks: Note that on some platforms (e.g. Mac), setting the background color of a control can change the performance characteristics of the control and its children, since it must enable layers to do so.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.Control.HasFocus
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this instance has the keyboard input focus.
member.value: true if this instance has focus; otherwise, false.

member.summary: Attempts to set the keyboard input focus to this control, or the first child that accepts focus

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.Control.IsSuspended
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the layout of child controls is suspended.
member.value: true if this instance is suspended; otherwise, false.

member.name: M:Eto.Forms.Control.SuspendLayout
member.summary: Suspends the layout of child controls
member.remarks: This can be used to optimize some platforms while adding, removing, or changing many child controls at once. It disables the calculation of control positioning until is called. Each call to SuspendLayout() must be balanced with a call to .

member.name: M:Eto.Forms.Control.ResumeLayout
member.summary: Resumes the layout after it has been suspended, and performs a layout
member.remarks: This can be used to optimize some platforms while adding, removing, or changing many child controls at once. Each call to ResumeLayout() must be balanced with a call to before it.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.Control.ParentWindow

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.Control.SupportedPlatformCommands
member.summary: Gets the supported platform commands that can be used to hook up system functions to user defined logic
member.remarks: This lists all available commands that can be mapped using the method of the control.

member.name: M:Eto.Forms.Control.MapPlatformCommand(System.String,Eto.Forms.Command)
member.summary: Specifies a command to execute for a platform-specific command
member.remarks: Some platforms have specific system-defined commands that can be associated with a control. For example, the Mac platform's cut/copy/paste functionality is defined by the system, and if you want to hook into it, you can use this to map it to your own defined logic. The valid values of the parameter are defined by each platform, and a list can be retrieved using
member.param: Command to execute, or null to restore to the default behavior

member.summary: Gets or sets the size of the control. Use -1 to specify auto sizing for either the width and/or height.

Setting the size of controls is entirely optional as most controls will size themselves appropriately. When specifying a size, it will be used as the desired size of the control. The container will reposition and resize the control depending on the available size.

member.name: M:Eto.Forms.Control.IHandler.SuspendLayout
member.summary: Suspends the layout of child controls
member.remarks: This can be used to optimize some platforms while adding, removing, or changing many child controls at once. It disables the calculation of control positioning until is called. Each call to SuspendLayout() must be balanced with a call to .

member.name: M:Eto.Forms.Control.IHandler.ResumeLayout
member.summary: Resumes the layout after it has been suspended, and performs a layout
member.remarks: This can be used to optimize some platforms while adding, removing, or changing many child controls at once. Each call to ResumeLayout() must be balanced with a call to before it.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.Control.IHandler.Visible
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether this is visible to the user.
member.remarks: When the visibility of a control is set to false, it will still occupy space in the layout, but not be shown. The only exception is for controls like the , which will hide a pane if the visibility of one of the panels is changed.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.Control.IHandler.SupportedPlatformCommands

member.remarks: This lists all available commands that can be mapped using the method of the control.

member.name: M:Eto.Forms.Control.IHandler.MapPlatformCommand(System.String,Eto.Forms.Command)
member.summary: Specifies a command to execute for a platform-specific command
member.remarks: Some platforms have specific system-defined commands that can be associated with a control. For example, the Mac platform's cut/copy/paste functionality is defined by the system, and if you want to hook into it, you can use this to map it to your own defined logic. The valid values of the parameter are defined by each platform, and a list can be retrieved using
member.param: Command to execute, or null to restore to the default behavior

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.Control.IHandler.TabIndex
member.summary: Gets or sets the tab index order for this control within its container.
member.remarks:
This sets the order when using the tab key to cycle through controls
Note that some platforms (Gtk and WinForms) may not support setting the context of the tab order to StackLayout or DynamicLayout containers and may not behave exactly as expected. Use the flag to determine if it is supported.
member.value: The index of the control in the tab order.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class with a hint whether it is intended for a large canvas
member.remarks:
Some platforms can optimize large canvases, such as mobile platforms by tiling the painting of the canvas.
A large canvas is one that is larger than the intended screen size.
Platforms are not required to change the behaviour of the drawable depending on this value. Desktop platforms typically do not change their behaviour based on this.
member.param: If set to true the drawable is created to have a large canvas.

member.name: T:Eto.Forms.GridViewDragInfo
member.summary: Extra drag information when dragging to a .
member.remarks: Use this information to determine where the user is dragging to, and also to change where the drag indicator will be shown by modifying the Item and ChildIndex properties.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.GridViewDragInfo.Item
member.summary: Gets or sets the item the user is dragging to.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.GridViewDragInfo.Index
member.summary: Gets or sets the insertion index where the user is dragging to as a child of Item, or -1 if dragging ontop of the Item.
member.remarks:
This is useful if the user is dragging inbetween existing items, or the beginning or end of a child list.
Only some platforms may support this property, otherwise it will always return -1.
member.value: The insertion index where the user is dragging to, otherwise -1.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.GridViewDragInfo.Position
member.summary: Gets the position of the ChildIndex relative to the item under the mouse cursor.
member.remarks: When dragging between items, this will tell you if the ChildIndex specified is after or before the item under the mouse cursor. This allows you to adjust the Item and ChildIndex.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.GridViewDragInfo.Control
member.summary: Gets the parent tree control this info is for.
member.value: The parent tree for the drag info.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.GridViewDragInfo.IsChanged
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this is changed.
member.remarks: This will return true if the or have been set. This is useful for platform implementations to determine if the drop target has been modified.
member.value: true if is changed; otherwise, false.

member.summary: Helper to restrict the drop to insert items only without allowing draging over existing items.

member.name: T:Eto.Forms.Label
member.summary: Displays a string of text on the form

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.Label.Wrap
member.summary: Gets or sets the wrap mode for the text
member.remarks:
This defines the soft wrapping for the label's text. Hard wraps can be placed in the text with newline characters.
Wrapping will only occur if the label's width is smaller than the space needed for the text. If you are autosizing your control, it may get autosized to the width so you will have to add constraints to the container or explicitly set the size.
member.value: The wrapping mode for the text.

member.remarks: When auto sizing the label, this won't have an affect unless the label's container is larger than the text.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.NumericStepper.DecimalPlaces
member.summary: Gets or sets the number of digits to display after the decimal.
member.remarks:
The NumericStepper control will at least show the number of fraction digits as specified by this value, padded by zeros. The specifies the maximum number of fraction digits the control will display if the value has a value that can be represented by more digits. The property is rounded to the number of fraction digits specified by .
Note that this does not apply if you have specified
member.value: The number of decimal places to always show.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.NumericStepper.Increment
member.summary: Gets or sets the value to increment when the user clicks on the stepper buttons.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.NumericStepper.MaximumDecimalPlaces
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum number of decimal places that can be shown.
member.remarks:
Specifies how many fraction digits can be shown if required to display the specified . The number of digits shown will be at least the number of digits specified by . The and the display is rounded to the number of fraction digits specified by this value. for an example of how the MaximumDecimalPlaces can be used.
Note that this does not apply if you have specified .
member.value: The maximum number of decimal places that will be shown.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.NumericStepper.FormatString
member.summary: Gets or sets the format string for the display of the numeric value.
member.remarks:
This can be used to specify standard or custom format strings used via . The exact output is determined using the specified .
For example "c" would show a currency value.
Any extra non-numeric or separator characters are stripped when parsing the string so that you can include extra (non-numeric) string values while still allowing the user to change the numeric string.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.NumericStepper.CultureInfo
member.summary: Specifies the culture to show the numeric value in (default is ).
member.remarks: This is used to format the numeric value, and when using the it determines the character(s) used for the thousands separator, decimal separator, and currency symbol.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.NumericStepper.IHandler.Increment
member.summary: Gets or sets the value to increment when the user clicks on the stepper buttons.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.NumericStepper.IHandler.TextColor
member.summary: Gets or sets the color of the text.
member.remarks: By default, the text will get a color based on the user's theme. However, this is usually black.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.NumericStepper.IHandler.MaximumDecimalPlaces
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum number of decimal places that can be shown.
member.remarks: Specifies how many fraction digits can be shown if required to display the specified . The number of digits shown will be at least the number of digits specified by . The and the display is rounded to the number of fraction digits specified by this value.
member.value: The maximum number of decimal places that will be shown.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.NumericStepper.IHandler.FormatString
member.summary: Gets or sets the format string for the display of the numeric value.
member.remarks:
This can be used to specify standard or custom format strings used via . The exact output is determined using the specified .
For example "c" would show a currency value.
Any extra non-numeric or separator characters are stripped when parsing the string so that you can include extra (non-numeric) string values while still allowing the user to change the numeric string.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.NumericStepper.IHandler.CultureInfo
member.summary: Specifies the culture to show the numeric value in (default is ).
member.remarks: This is used to format the numeric value, and when using the it determines the character(s) used for the thousands separator, decimal separator, and currency symbol.

member.name: T:Eto.Forms.RadioButton
member.summary: Control to present a button to choose from a set of options
member.remarks:
The RadioButton works with other radio buttons to present a list of options that the user can select from. When a radio button is toggled on, all others that are linked together will be toggled off.
To link radio buttons together, use the constructor to specify the controller radio button, which can be created with the default constructor.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.Scrollable.IHandler.ExpandContentHeight

member.remarks: Most desktop platforms allow the user to modify the position of the splitter, though some (notibly iOS) do not. The of the splitter determines how the controls are laid out, either horizontally or vertically.

member.name: T:Eto.Forms.AutoSelectMode
member.summary: Enumeration of the modes for auto selecting text.

member.name: F:Eto.Forms.AutoSelectMode.OnFocus
member.summary: Selects the text when the control recieves focus, unless the user clicks at a point in the text with the I beam cursor.

member.name: F:Eto.Forms.AutoSelectMode.Never
member.summary:
The text is never automatically selected. When the text of the control is set to a different value, the cursor usually will be at the end of the text input.
The last selection of the control is also usually kept in this mode.

member.name: F:Eto.Forms.AutoSelectMode.Always
member.summary:
Selects the text when the control recieves focus regardless of whether the user clicked at a point in the text, or the last selection.
On macOS, if the user clicks and drags to select some text it will not select all text.

member.name: T:Eto.Forms.ThemedControlHandler`3
member.summary: Base class for implementing Eto control handlers using other Eto controls.
member.remarks:
This allows a single implementation to be used in multiple platforms and is useful in a couple of scenarios:
a) Creating default implementations of a control on platforms that do not support the control natively. b) Implementing a control with a non-native look and feel that is consistent across platforms.
member.typeparam: The Eto control used to create the custom implementation, e.g. Panel
The control being implemented, e.g. TabControl
The callback inferface for the control, e.g. TabControl.ICallback

member.name: M:Eto.Forms.ThemedControlHandler`3.Initialize
member.summary: Called to initialize this widget after it has been constructed
member.remarks: Override this to initialize any of the platform objects. This is called in the widget constructor, after all of the widget's constructor code has been called.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.ThemedControlHandler`3.BackgroundColor
member.summary: Gets or sets the color for the background of the control
member.remarks: Note that on some platforms (e.g. Mac), setting the background color of a control can change the performance characteristics of the control and its children, since it must enable layers to do so.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.ThemedControlHandler`3.VisualControls
member.summary: Gets an enumeration of controls that are in the visual tree.
member.remarks: This is used to specify which controls are contained by this instance that are part of the visual tree. This should include all controls including non-logical Eto controls used for layout.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.ThemedControlHandler`3.PropagateLoadEvents
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether /// events are propagated to the inner control
member.remarks: Typically this should be true so that the events are propagated, but when you set the control hierarchy manually, such as a on a , you can return false here since the load events will be handled automatically by the internal eto controls.
member.value: true if propagate load events; otherwise, false.

member.name: M:Eto.Forms.ThemedControlHandler`3.SuspendLayout
member.summary: Suspends the layout of child controls
member.remarks: This can be used to optimize some platforms while adding, removing, or changing many child controls at once. It disables the calculation of control positioning until is called. Each call to SuspendLayout() must be balanced with a call to .

member.name: M:Eto.Forms.ThemedControlHandler`3.ResumeLayout
member.summary: Resumes the layout after it has been suspended, and performs a layout
member.remarks: This can be used to optimize some platforms while adding, removing, or changing many child controls at once. Each call to ResumeLayout() must be balanced with a call to before it.

member.name: T:Eto.Forms.TreeGridViewDragInfo
member.summary: Extra drag information when dragging to a .
member.remarks: Use this information to determine where the user is dragging to, and also to change where the drag indicator will be shown by modifying the Item and ChildIndex properties.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.TreeGridViewDragInfo.Parent
member.summary: Gets or sets the parent node of the to drag to.
member.remarks:
Normally you would only need to set to specify which node to drag to.
However, in the case of dragging to below the Parent as inserting a first child you would set Parent to the node, to null, and to .

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.TreeGridViewDragInfo.ChildIndex
member.summary: Gets the index of the relative to the .

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.TreeGridViewDragInfo.InsertIndex
member.summary: Gets or sets the insertion index where the user is dragging to as a child of Item, or -1 if dragging over the Item.
member.remarks: This is useful if the user is dragging between existing items, or the beginning or end of a child list.
member.value: The insertion index where the user is dragging to, otherwise -1 if dragging over an item.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.TreeGridViewDragInfo.Position
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the drop should insert before, after, or over the .
member.remarks: When this is Before or After, you can use the to determine what index to insert the item as a child of the node.
member.value: The position to insert the dropped item, or over.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.TreeGridViewDragInfo.Control
member.summary: Gets the parent tree control this info is for.
member.value: The parent tree for the drag info.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.TreeGridViewDragInfo.IsChanged
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this is changed.
member.remarks: This will return true if the or have been set. This is useful for platform implementations to determine if the drop target has been modified.
member.value: true if is changed; otherwise, false.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.TreeGridViewDragInfo.Item
member.summary: Gets or sets the item to drag to, or null if dragging below the node.
member.remarks:
This specifies the target item to drag to. Note that if is Before or After, then you should use to insert the nodes at that specified location.
If you do not want to allow inserting, use in the event, or you can also use to only allow inserting items.

member.name: M:Eto.Forms.TreeGridViewDragInfo.RestrictToOver
member.summary: Helper to restrict to drop on top an existing item without allowing any insertion.

member.name: M:Eto.Forms.TreeGridViewDragInfo.RestrictToInsert
member.summary: Helper to restrict the drop to insert items only without allowing draging over existing items.

member.name: M:Eto.Forms.TreeGridViewDragInfo.RestrictToNode(System.Object,System.Int32)
member.summary: Restricts the drop to an item or a child within the specified number of levels.
member.param: Item to restrict the drop to, or any of its children
Number of child levels to allow, or -1 to allow any number of levels
member.returns: True if the drag was restricted, or false if the user is already dragging over the specified item or its children.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: The parent widget that this info belongs to
Parent of the item dragging to.
Item user is dragging to, or null if dragging as a child of the parent node.
Index of the item relative to the parent if known, otherwise null to determine the index when requsted.
The position of the cursor relative to the item or parent if item is null.

member.name: T:Eto.Forms.WebView
member.summary: Control to show a browser control that can display html and execute javascript.
member.remarks:
Most platforms have built-in support for a browser control, which by default this will use.
There are other browser implementations available, such as Chromium, etc. You can create your own handler for the web view if you want to use a different browser control.

member.summary: Occurs when the document is fully loaded.

member.summary: Occurs when a document starts loading.
member.remarks: This fires when the document shown is changed, and notifies which url is being loaded. You can cancel the loading of a page through this event, though you should check the to determine if it is for the main frame, or a child frame.

member.name: E:Eto.Forms.WebView.OpenNewWindow
member.summary: Occurs when the page prompts to open a link in a new window
member.remarks:
This event will occur when a user or script opens a new link in a new window.
This is usually when an anchor's target is set to _blank, or a specific window name.
You must handle this event to perform an action, otherwise no action will occur.

member.name: T:Eto.Forms.SelectableFilterCollection`1
member.summary: Collection that can filter/sort the items, and keep a selection of items in the original list.
member.remarks:
This collection is useful when you want the selection to act independant of the filter. This class will keep the selected items based on the original list, not based on the filtered view.
For example, if you select an item and set the filter that eliminates the item from the view, the will still return the same selected item until it is unselected from the view or from this class directly.

member.summary: Occurs when a mouse button is released

member.summary: Occurs when mouse moves within the bounds of the control, or when the mouse is captured
member.remarks: The mouse is captured after a event within the control, and is released when the mouse button is released

member.name: E:Eto.Forms.IMouseInputSource.MouseEnter
member.summary: Occurs when the mouse enters the bounds of the control

member.name: E:Eto.Forms.IMouseInputSource.MouseLeave
member.summary: Occurs when mouse leaves the bounds of the control

member.name: E:Eto.Forms.IMouseInputSource.MouseDown
member.summary: Occurs when a mouse button has been pressed
member.remarks: Controls will typically capture the mouse after a mouse button is pressed and will be released only after the event.

member.name: E:Eto.Forms.IMouseInputSource.MouseDoubleClick
member.summary: Occurs when a mouse button is double clicked within the bounds of the control
member.remarks:
If you do not set the property to true, and the default behaviour of the control does not accept double clicks, the event will be called for each click of the mouse button.
For example, if the user clicks twice in succession, the following will be called: 1. MouseDown for the first click 2. MouseDoubleClick for the second click 3. If Handled has not been set in #2, MouseDown will be called a 2nd time

member.name: E:Eto.Forms.IMouseInputSource.MouseWheel

member.name: T:Eto.Forms.DynamicLayout
member.summary: Dynamic and extensible layout
member.remarks:
The dynamic layout allows you to build a complex structure of controls easily. The core functionality allows you to build a hierarchical set of tables with rows and columns of controls.
A vertical section begins a new table, whereas a horizontal section refers to a row in a table. The dynamic layout intrinsically starts with a vertical section.
You can define your layout verbosely or succinctly as you see fit. The Begin.../End... methods allow you define the vertical/horizontal sections individually with separate commands, whereas you can also create a layout entirely with a constructor or initializer pattern using the , , and properties.
To learn about how scaling works, see

member.remarks: The layout automatically will be created during the or

member.summary: Creates a new section where all controls will be centered together.

member.name: M:Eto.Forms.DynamicLayout.Add(Eto.Forms.Control,System.Nullable{System.Boolean},System.Nullable{System.Boolean})
member.summary: Add the control with the optional scaling
member.remarks:
This will add either horizontally or vertically depending on whether or was called last.
The x/y scaling specified applies either to the entire column or row in the parent table that the control was added to, not just this individual control.
member.param: Control to add, or null to add blank space
Xscale for this control and any in the same column
Yscale for this control and any in the same row

member.name: T:Eto.Forms.TableCell
member.summary: Represents a cell in a

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.TableCell.ScaleWidth
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether this will scale its width
member.remarks:
All controls in the same column of this cell will get the same scaling value. Scaling will make the column expand to fit the rest of the width of the container, minus the preferred width of any non-scaled columns.
If there are no columns with width scaling, the last column will automatically get scaled.
With scaling turned off, cells in the column will fit the preferred size of the widest control.
member.value: true if scale width; otherwise, false.

member.name: T:Eto.Forms.TableLayout
member.summary: Layout for controls in a table
member.remarks: This is similar to an html table, though each control will fill its entire cell.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.TableLayout.Controls
member.summary: Gets an enumeration of controls that are directly contained by this container

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.TableLayout.Rows
member.summary: Gets the collection of rows in the table

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.TableLayout.Dimensions
member.summary: Gets the dimensions of the table in cells.

member.name: M:Eto.Forms.TableLayout.AutoSized(Eto.Forms.Control,System.Nullable{Eto.Drawing.Padding},System.Boolean)
member.summary: Creates a table layout with an auto sized control.
member.remarks:
Since controls fill an entire cell, you can use this method to create a layout that will ensure that the specified gets its preferred size instead of stretching to fill the container.
By default, extra space will be added to the right and bottom, unless is true, which will add equal space to the top/bottom, and left/right.
member.returns: The table layout with the auto sized control.
member.param: If set to true center the control, otherwise control is upper left of the container.

member.name: M:Eto.Forms.TableLayout.Horizontal(Eto.Forms.TableCell[])
member.summary: Creates a horizontal table layout with the specified cells.
member.remarks:
Since table layouts are by default vertical by defining the rows and the cells for each row, it is verbose to create nested tables when you want a horizontal table. E.g. new TableLayout(new TableRow(...)).
This method is used to easily create a single row table layout with a horizontal set of cells. E.g. TableLayout.Horizontal(...)
member.returns: A new single row table layout with the specified cells

member.name: M:Eto.Forms.TableLayout.HorizontalScaled(Eto.Forms.TableCell[])
member.summary: Creates a horizontal table layout with the specified cells scaled equally.
member.remarks:
Since table layouts are by default vertical by defining the rows and the cells for each row, it is verbose to create nested tables when you want a horizontal table. E.g. new TableLayout(new TableRow(...)).
This method is used to easily create a single row table layout with a horizontal set of cells. E.g. TableLayout.HorizontalScaled(...)
The difference between Horizontal and HorizontalScaled is that this method sets ScaleWidth on each cell.
member.returns: A new single row table layout with the specified cells

member.name: M:Eto.Forms.TableLayout.Horizontal(System.Int32,Eto.Forms.TableCell[])
member.summary: Creates a horizontal table layout with the specified cells.
member.remarks:
Since table layouts are by default vertical by defining the rows and the cells for each row, it is verbose to create nested tables when you want a horizontal table. E.g. new TableLayout(new TableRow(...)).
This method is used to easily create a single row table layout with a horizontal set of cells. E.g. TableLayout.Horizontal(...)
member.returns: A new single row table layout with the specified cells

member.name: T:Eto.Forms.IListItem
member.summary: Interface for an item in a list control.
member.remarks:
If you have a list of your own objects, it is more efficient to use them directly with the list control by passing a collection to the DataStore property, and using TextBinding/KeyBinding to specify how to get/set the Text and Key properties.
Otherwise, use to define items. This may be depricated in the future.

member.name: T:Eto.Forms.FixedMaskedTextProvider
member.summary: Implements a fixed masked text provider, using the standard System.ComponentModel.MaskedTextProvider.
member.remarks:
This wraps the standard provider in an interface used by the so that we can provide different implementations of masked text providers.
The implementation of this is defined in each platform assembly so that we can use this from a PCL assembly.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.FixedMaskedTextProvider.Culture
member.summary: Gets the culture for the mask, as specified in the constructor.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.FixedMaskedTextProvider.Mask
member.summary: Gets the mask for this provider, as specified in the constructor.
member.remarks:
The mask format can consist of the following characters:
0 - Required digit from 0-9. 9 - Optional digit or space. # - Optional digit, space, or sign (+/-). If blank, then it is output as a space in the Text value. L - Required upper or lowercase letter. ? - Optional upper or lowercase letter. & - Required character. If is true, then behaves like L. C - Optional character. If is true, then behaves like ?. A - Required alphanumeric character. If is true, then behaves like L. a - Optional alphanumeric. If is true, then behaves like ?. . - Decimal placeholder based on the specified for the mask. , - Thousands placeholder based on the specified for the mask. : - Time separator based on the specified for the mask. / - Date separator based on the specified for the mask. $ - Currency symbol based on the specified for the mask. < - Shift all characters that follow to lower case. > - Shift all characters that follow to upper case. | - Disables a previous shift to upper or lower case. \ - Escape the following character into a literal. All other characters are treated as literal and cannot be moved or deleted.

member.value: true to allow prompt as input; otherwise, false.

member.name: T:Eto.Forms.IMaskedTextProvider
member.summary: Interface for a masked text provider that can be used with .
member.remarks:
This defines the interface that the uses when inserting, deleting, and clearing characters from a masked string.
This can be implemented by both variable and fixed masks (unlike the standard System.ComponentModel.MaskedTextProvider), and provides a way to create your own completely custom masks. You can also use the as a base for custom masks to implement the default functionality.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.MenuBar.IncludeSystemItems
member.summary: Gets or sets which system items will be automatically included with the menu.
member.remarks:
Some operating systems, such as OS X require you to create your own standard items to enable the ability to do things such as close a window, cut/paste, hide apps, quit an app, etc. By default, the menu will be merged with your custom menu so that all of these system functions will work.
For Quit and About menu items, use the and instead so that they are placed in the correct/expected location on every platform.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.MenuBar.SystemCommands
member.summary: Gets the system commands for the menu.
member.remarks: These system commands are used for any of the items added when is set to anything other than . You can modify this collection to remove items from the system menu, or update which items should be used instead. This is only needed for advanced scenarios and should not be required to be used in normal circumstances.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.MenuBar.Items
member.summary: Gets the collection of menu items

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.MenuBar.QuitItem
member.summary: Gets or sets the quit item for the application.
member.remarks: This allows you to set the quit item for the application. Some platforms (OS X) may add a quit item to the menu even if one is not defined as it is standard practice to allow users to quit the application with a menu item. This will be in the File menu for most platforms, and the Application menu for OS X.
member.value: The quit item on the menu.

member.remarks: This allows you to set an item to show an about dialog for the application. OS X will place this in the Application menu, other platforms place this at the bottom of the Help menu.
member.value: The about item on the menu.

member.name: T:Eto.Forms.RadioMenuItem
member.summary: Menu item to choose from a set of options
member.remarks:
The RadioMenuItem works with other radio items to present a list of options that the user can select from. When a radio button is toggled on, all others that are linked together will be toggled off.
To link radio buttons together, use the constructor to specify the controller radio item, which can be created with the default constructor.

member.summary: Gets an enumerable of display screens available on the current system.
member.value: The screens of the current system.
