member.summary: Gets the display bounds of all screens on the current system.
member.value: The display bounds of all screens.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.Screen.PrimaryScreen
member.summary: Gets the primary screen of the current system.
member.remarks: This is typically the user's main screen.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.Screen.DPI
member.summary: Gets the logical Dots/Pixels Per Inch of the screen.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.Screen.Scale
member.summary: Gets the logical scale of the pixels of the screen vs. points.
member.remarks:
The scale can be used to translate points to pixels. E.g.
var pixels = points * screen.Scale;
This is useful when creating fonts that need to be a certain pixel size.
Since this is a logical scale, this will give you the 'recommended' pixel size that will appear to be the same physical size, even on retina displays.
member.value: The logical scale of pixels per point.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.Screen.RealDPI
member.summary: Gets the real Dots/Pixels Per Inch of the screen, accounting for retina displays.
member.remarks: This is similar to , however will give you the 'real' DPI of the screen. For example, a Retina display on OS X will have the RealDPI twice the DPI reported.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.Screen.RealScale
member.summary: Gets the real scale of the pixels of the screen vs. points.
member.remarks:
The scale can be used to translate points to 'real' pixels. E.g.
var pixels = points * screen.Scale;
This is useful when creating fonts that need to be a certain pixel size.
Since this is a real scale, this will give you the actual pixel size. This means on retina displays on OS X will appear to be half the physical size as regular displays.
member.value: The real scale of pixels per point.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.Screen.Bounds
member.summary: Gets the bounds of the display in the area.
member.remarks: The primary screen's upper left corner is always located at 0,0. A negative X/Y indicates that the screen location is to the left or top of the primary screen. A positive X/Y indicates that the screen location is to the right or bottom of the primary screen.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.Screen.WorkingArea
member.summary: Gets the working area of the display, excluding any menu/task bars, docks, etc.
member.remarks: This is useful to position your window in the usable area of the screen.
member.value: The working area of the screen.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.Screen.BitsPerPixel
member.summary: Gets the number of bits each pixel uses to represent its color value.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.Screen.IsPrimary
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this screen is the primary/main screen.
member.value: true if this is the primary screen; otherwise, false.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.Screen.LogicalPixelSize
member.summary: Gets the number of physical pixels per logical pixel of this display.
member.remarks:
On Retina/HighDPI displays, this will usually return 2.0, but can also be a fraction of pixels. Non-retina will return 1.0.
This essentially returns the value of divided by .
member.value: The number of physical pixels for each logical pixel.

member.name: T:Eto.Forms.Screen.IHandler
member.summary: Handler interface for the .

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.Screen.IHandler.Scale
member.summary: Gets the logical scale of the pixels of the screen vs. points.
member.remarks: This scale should be based on a standard 72dpi screen.
member.value: The logical scale of pixels per point.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.Screen.IHandler.RealScale
member.summary: Gets the real scale of the pixels of the screen vs. points.
member.remarks: This should be based on a standard 72dpi screen, and is useful for retina displays when the real DPI is double the logical DPI. E.g. 1440x900 logical screen size is actually 2880x1800 pixels.
member.value: The real scale of pixels per point.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.Screen.IHandler.BitsPerPixel
member.summary: Gets the number of bits each pixel uses to represent its color value.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.Screen.IHandler.Bounds

member.remarks: The primary screen's upper left corner is always located at 0,0. A negative X/Y indicates that the screen location is to the left or top of the primary screen. A positive X/Y indicates that the screen location is to the right or bottom of the primary screen.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.Screen.IHandler.WorkingArea
member.summary: Gets the working area of the display, excluding any menu/task bars, docks, etc.
member.remarks: This is useful to position your window in the usable area of the screen.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.Screen.IHandler.IsPrimary

member.name: T:Eto.Forms.ToolBarDock
member.summary: Docking mode hint for a
member.remarks:
Most platforms will not respect this, and is usually only necessary for constrained devices like iOS and Android. Each platform may have a different default docking mode, depending on the type of device. E.g. iPhone will by default show the toolbar on the bottom, whereas iPad and dekstop platforms will show it at the top by default.
Additionally, some platforms may choose to show the toolbar in a different way, e.g. the Navigation control on iPhone has a standard toolbar available, so if you are using one it will attempt to use its toolbar to provide the best native experience.

member.name: T:Eto.Forms.UITimer
member.summary: Provides a timer that executes code at a specified interval on the UI thread
member.remarks:
This provides a way to execute UI code at a specified . Note that this is not a high-resolution timer, and you should avoid setting a small interval otherwise the UI may become unresponsive depending on the logic in the executed code.
This typically executes the code on the UI main loop, thus the accuracy of the timer is dependent on the other UI code executing.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.Window.Owner
member.summary: Gets or sets the owner of this window.
member.remarks: This sets the parent window that has ownership over this window. For a , this will be the window that will be disabled while the modal dialog is shown. With a , the specified owner will always be below the current window when shown, and will still be responsive to user input. Typically, but not always, the window will move along with the owner.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.Window.Screen
member.summary: Gets the screen this window is mostly contained in. Typically defined by the screen center of the window is visible.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.Window.Menu
member.summary: Gets or sets the menu bar for this window
member.remarks: Some platforms have a global menu bar (e.g. ubuntu, OS X). When the winow is in focus, the global menu bar will be changed to reflect the menu assigned.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.Window.Icon
member.summary: Gets or sets the icon for the window to show in the menu bar.
member.remarks:
The icon should have many variations, such as 16x16, 24x24, 32x32, 48x48, 64x64, etc. This ensures that the many places it is used (title bar, task bar, switch window, etc) all have optimized icon sizes.
For OS X, the application icon is specified in the .app bundle, not by this value.

member.remarks: This may hide or disable the minimize button on the title bar.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.Window.Minimizable
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether this can be minimized.
member.remarks: This may hide or disable the maximize button on the title bar.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.Window.ShowInTaskbar
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether this will show in the taskbar.

member.value: true if the window will show in taskbar; otherwise, false.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.Window.LogicalPixelSize
member.summary: Gets the number of pixels per logical pixel when on a high DPI display.
member.remarks:
This indicates the number of pixels per logical pixel. All units in Eto.Forms such as control size, drawing operations, etc are in logical pixels. When not in high DPI, this will be 1.0; Retina displays in OS X will return 2; and in windows this matches the scale set in the monitor settings.
Use the to detect when the window is moved to a display with a different DPI.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.Window.IHandler.LogicalPixelSize
member.summary: Gets the number of pixels per logical pixel when on a high DPI display.
member.remarks:
This indicates the number of pixels per logical pixel. All units in Eto.Forms such as control size, drawing operations, etc are in logical pixels. When not in high DPI, this will be 1.0; Retina displays in OS X will return 2; and in windows this matches the scale set in the monitor settings.
Use the to detect when the window is moved to a display with a different DPI.

member.name: T:Eto.NamespaceInfo
member.summary: Helper class to get information about a namespace and assembly
member.remarks:
This is used to easily split the namespace and assembly parts from a string, and get the assembly instance. For example, "Eto.Drawing, Eto" will be split into "Eto.Drawing" for the namespace and the instance for the Eto.dll.
Used primarily for serialization and conversion of types.

member.summary: Specifies that the supports creating a Control for each cell. If not specified, then the CustomCell will paint its content when not in edit mode.

member.name: F:Eto.PlatformFeatures.DrawableWithTransparentContent
member.summary: Specifies that the supports automatic transparent background for its Content. If not specified, then setting the content may not work as intended (most often not rendering with transparent background, thus overpainting the drawable).

member.name: F:Eto.PlatformFeatures.TabIndexWithCustomContainers
member.summary:
Specifies the is based on the logical tree, not the visual tree. Both GTK and WinForms do not support creating a custom tab focus and is based on the direct containers.
For example, setting a TabIndex for controls in DynamicLayout and StackLayout might not behave as expected on platforms that do not support this.

member.name: P:Eto.Platform.Instance
member.summary: Gets the platform for the current thread
member.remarks:
Typically you'd have only one platform active at a time, and this holds an instance to that value. The current platform is set automatically by the class when it is initially created.
This will return a different value for each thread, so if you have multiple platforms running (e.g. GTK + Mac for OS X), then this will allow for that.
This will be used when creating controls. To create controls on a different platform outside of its own thread, use the property.

member.name: P:Eto.Platform.Detect
member.summary: Returns the current generator, or detects the generator to use if no current generator is set.
member.remarks:
This detects the platform to use based on the generator assemblies available and the current OS.
For windows, it will prefer WPF to Windows Forms. Mac OS X will prefer the Mac platform. Other unix-based platforms will prefer GTK.

member.name: T:Eto.PropertyStore
member.summary: A storage for properties and events of a class
member.remarks:
This is used by object to minimize the footprint of each instance. For example, the class has around 20 events, each would take up to 4 bytes on a 32 bit system for a total overhead of 80 bytes per instance. Most of the events won't be handled on most controls, so using a dictionary can dramatically reduce the size.
This can also be used for rarely used properties that do not need to be extremely performant when getting or setting the value.

member.remarks: This is used to attach/remove events

member.summary: Adds a generic event delegate with the specified key
member.remarks:
This should be called in an event's add accessor. If you are adding a handler-based event, call instead, which will automatically tell the handler that it needs to be wired up.
You can use any subclass of for the type of event handler
To trigger the event, use .

Delegate to add to the event

member.summary: Adds a handler-based event delegate with the specified key
member.remarks:
This should be called in an event's add accessor. This is used for any event that should be triggered by the platform handler. This will call with the specified for the first subscription to the event.
You can use any subclass of for the type of event handler
To trigger the event, use

member.name: M:Eto.PropertyStore.Set``1(System.Object,``0,``0)
member.summary: Set the value for the specified property key, removing the value from the dictionary if it is the default value of T.
member.remarks: This can be used as an optimized way to set the value in the dictionary as if the value set equal to the (e.g. null for reference types, false for bool, 0 for int, etc), then it will be removed from the dictionary instead of just set to the value, reducing memory usage. The should be passed the same default when retrieving the parameter value.
member.param: Key of the property to set.

member.name: T:Eto.StyleWidgetHandler`1
member.summary: Delegate to handle styling a widget

member.name: T:Eto.StyleHandler`1

member.name: T:Eto.Style
member.summary: Style manager for widgets
member.remarks:
Styles allow you to attach custom platform-specific logic to a widget. In your platform-specific assembly, use Style.Add<H>(string, StyleHandler<H>) to add the style logic with the same id.
Typically, your styles will be added in your platform-specific executable, before your application is run.

member.name: E:Eto.Style.StyleWidget
member.summary: Event to handle when a widget has being styled

member.name: M:Eto.Style.Add``1(System.String,Eto.StyleWidgetHandler{``0})
member.summary: Adds a style for a widget
member.remarks:
Styling a widget allows you to access the widget, but not the platform-specific controls (in a type-safe way).
Typically, you'd use Style.Add<H>(string, StyleHandler<H>) instead, which will add a style based on the widget handler, which will give you direct and type safe access to platform-specifics of the widget.
member.typeparam: Type of the widget to style
member.param: Delegate with your logic to style the widget

member.name: M:Eto.Style.Add``1(System.String,Eto.StyleHandler{``0})
member.summary: Adds a style for a widget handler
member.remarks:
Styling a widget handler allows you to access both the widget and the platform-specifics for the widget.
To use this, you would have to add a reference to one of the Eto.*.dll's so that you can utilize the platform handler directly. Typically this would be called before your application is run.
member.typeparam: Type of the handler that should be styled
member.param: Delegate with your logic to style the widget and/or platform control

member.name: T:Eto.Threading.Thread
member.summary: Provides access to platform-specific threading. Not all platforms implement this as you can use System.Threading.Thread instead in most cases.
member.remarks: Most platforms have a concept of threads, though some (e.g. WinRT) do not. This may be removed in a future version in favour of using Task.Run(), Task.Delay(), which works across all platforms on .net 4.5+ and PCL.

member.name: M:Eto.Widget.IHandler.HandleEvent(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Called to handle a specific event
member.remarks:
Most events are late bound by this method. Instead of wiring all events, this will be called with an event string that is defined by the control.
This is called automatically when attaching to events, but must be called manually when users of the control only override the event's On... method.

True if the event is default (e.g. overridden or via an event handler subscription)

member.name: P:Eto.Widget.ControlObject
member.summary: Gets the instance of the platform-specific object
member.remarks:
This can sometimes be useful to get the platform-specific object. Some handlers may not have any backing object for its functionality, so this may be null.
It is more preferred to use the and cast that to the platform-specific handler class which can give you additional methods and helpers to do common tasks.
For example, the object's handler for OS X has a AddFullScreenMenuItem property to specify if you want full screen support in your app.

member.name: P:Eto.WidgetHandler`2.Connector
member.summary: Gets a weak connector class to hook up events to the underlying control
member.remarks: Some frameworks (e.g. gtk, monomac, ios, android) keep track of references in a way that leak objects when there is a circular reference between the control and the handler. This is the case when registering events from the control to a method implemented in the handler. This instance can be used to connect the objects together using a weak reference to the handler, allowing controls to be garbage collected.

member.name: M:Eto.WidgetHandler`2.CreateConnector
member.summary: Creates the event connector for this control
member.remarks: This creates the weak connector to use for event registration and other purposes.

member.name: T:Eto.WidgetHandler`2.WeakConnector
member.summary: Connector for events to keep a weak reference to allow controls to be garbage collected when no longer referenced

member.name: P:Eto.WidgetHandler`2.WeakConnector.Handler
member.summary: Gets the handler that the connector is associated with
member.remarks: This property is used to access the handler instance to trigger events.
